body_html:
Can you link the install and the statement from NVIDIA that it is not supported? I will ask them what is up if I can get specific details. You do not have to install the driver and CUDA at the same time (at least on linux), you can install any version of CUDA that you want. NVIDIA is big into backwards compatibility, I am pretty sure you can still run CUDA 8.0 with the latest drivers if you really wanted. If you are getting an error can you take a screenshot, as I am not sure why the 1080ti and my 1080 work but not the 1050ti.

CUDA 9.0 is not deprecated, it was last patched on 07-JUNE-2018 (less than two months ago). Deprecated would mean no longer supported by NVIDIA. When CUDA 10 comes out CUDA 9.2 will move to the archive as well but it will not be considered deprecated. In my meetings with them we agreed it would be better to stick with CUDA 9.0 until 10.0 comes out due to having to force people to update to the latest drivers, which is difficult for many users especially schools and corporations. CUDA 10.x will be nice as it will not require constant driver updates.

If CUDA 9.0 is broken on Windows, I can escalate to NVIDIA and we can consider changing the windows install to use CUDA 9.2. I just need details that would allow someone to reproduce and understand the problem or a link where NVIDIA says it is not supported.
